bestBHT.bht: The perpetuity of Messiah's kingdom, as promised by the angel, requires this clause read as a parenthesis. Mary, with a humble and thankful heart, praises God for His mercy shown to His people, in accordance with His promise to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. This mercy should be remembered forever, as it extends to all true believers, both among Jews and Gentiles. The grace of God's promise and adoption have been offered to all nations, ensuring that His mercy endures for generations to come.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The sense requires this clause to be read as a parenthesis.
The perpetuity of Messiah's kingdom, as expressly promised by the angel.
Albert Barnes: He has dealt mercifully with the children of Israel, according as He promised Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
The mercy of God manifested to His people should be had in everlasting remembrance.
It is the language of a humble, thankful, pious, female heart praising God.
John Calvin: Mary does not merely explain who the Fathers were to whom God spake, but extends the power and result of the promises to all his posterity, provided they are the true seed of Abraham.

As many of the children of Abraham, according to the flesh, have been cut off by their unbelief, and have been thrown out as degenerate from the family of Abraham, so we, who were strangers, are admitted to it by faith, and regarded as the true seed of Abraham.

Let us therefore hold that, in consequence of God having formerly spoken to the fathers, the grace offered to them belongs equally to their posterity; and also, that the adoption has been extended to all nations, so that those, who were not by nature children of Abraham, may be his spiritual seed.
Philip Schaff: Yet God’s remembrance of His mercy is connected with His truthfulness to His promise.
The promise: ‘In thy seed shall all the nations of the earth be blessed’ (Genesis 22:18), indicates the universal character of God’s mercy.
God has helped Israel in order to remember His mercy forever.
John Gill: To Abraham and to his seed for ever: not his natural, but his spiritual seed; both among Jews and Gentiles, to the end of the world."
To these God promised this mercy of a Saviour and Redeemer, and to these he performs it."
John Wesley: To his seed — His spiritual seed: all true believers.

bhtAttempts.bht: The perpetuity of Messiah's kingdom, as expressly promised by the angel, requires this clause to be read as a parenthesis. Mary, with a humble and thankful heart, praises God for the mercy He has shown to His people, in accordance with His promise to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. This mercy is to be remembered forever, as it extends to all who are the true seed of Abraham, both among Jews and Gentiles. God's promise and grace have been offered not only to the fathers but also to their posterity, and the adoption has been extended to all nations. Thus, the spiritual seed of Abraham, all true believers, will experience the mercy of God for generations to come.

Mary praises God, as the perpetuity of Messiah's kingdom requires this clause to be read as a parenthesis. The mercy shown to His people, in accordance with His promise to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, should be remembered forever. This mercy extends to all true believers, among Jews and Gentiles, and the grace of God's promise and adoption have been offered to all nations. Thus, His mercy will endure throughout generations.
